If you really want to pitch down audio, the first thing to do is to raise the sample rate a lot. Think of this as the video frame rate, but for audio. Typically people record at 44100 or 48000 samples per second. If you want to be able to play back something 1000x slower, you would in theory need to record at a 1000x higher sample rate, which is probably impossible. 3-4x speeds are possible with (some) sound studio grade equipment, and with lab equipent 10x should be doable.

The reason the audio is doing what it does is because every single sound, regardless of if it’s digital or not, is just a series of ticks layered together to make a sound. The term Sine Wave describes the wave generated by a wave that has an even up and down in audio. The speed at which these sounds hits our eardrum is the hertz that many people have heard about and it’s basically how often a note hits your eardrum per second. The standard A Note at 440 hertz hits your ear at 440 vibrations per second. Do lower that by an octave would divide that number in half, then that number to lower another octave would be half, and so on. Once you get below twenty hertz, for a humans hearing we don’t even hear notes anymore. It just sounds like a noise. One hertz would hit a sound at your ear once per second. 100th speed is actually much slower than that one per second, but despite that, I myself cannot actually explain why the audio starts to distort, unless it’s got something to do with the way computers handle sound and it can’t produce notes low enough so it just boosts the sound to make it sound slower.

I think it would also be interesting to actually get into the physics of sound and why it just wouldn't work right where you're recording things where the movement exceeds the speed of sound. Additionally, the wavelength of the sound at that playback speed would not have the information density to provide anything meaningful to the viewer. The only produced frequencies that would be audible would have to be incredibly high to begin with. Once slowed down to video speed, most sounds would be well below the audible frequency range.

Some of the implementations do suffer from significant digital artifacts like stuttering if you stretch too far, but others are remarkably transparent. Sampling the audio faster won't help. Another way to look at the problem is that the information in audio is so incredibly band limited relative to light. High-speed videography allows us to capture what we're missing with our eyes, which is a lot. The reason that trying to slow down audio to match the super-slow visual doesn't work is that the pressure waves in the air aren't doing anything of interest at that kind of speed. We're just not missing as much temporally with our ears.

The real "real" sound would be interesting transposed down to the same amount as the video is slowed down. I mean the ultrasound (about>20kHz) all the way up to hypersound (>=1GHz). The problem is that conventional microphones and recording electronics do not pick that up (the usual cutoff is around the start of ultrasound ~20kHz). Furthermore AFAIK this sound its strongly dampened in the atmosphere so some kind of "extreme-ultrasound-microphone" (don't know if these exist) would need to be placed very close to the source. Surprisingly a quick web-search does not turn up much (beside HIFU face-lifting nonsense).
Still a white patch on the map?
What would one find there usually? A rather silent monotonous tone or something more surprising and varied? The sound is probably not everyday experience relateable, like the engineered fake sound is, but I think it might be pretty interesting. Kind of like the radio-infrasound that the gas giants emit. (In this case its transposed in the other direction and recording is easier (just an antennae in space).

Slowing audio (analogically) - pitch/freq/amp - at the rate you are recording video would make it extremely infrasonic (fractions of Hertz) - completely inaudible. Digital algorithms/sampling source data synthesizes it to an audible level.

Slowing down the audio from a regular recording device isn't a good enough source for playing back in slow-mo. If you're recording at the standard of 44.1 kHz, but recording it for 100k FPS, there's just not enough data to slow down, it would be like slowing down 60 FPS and then interpolating the 1000's of missing frames. You would need to find a recording device that can sample closer to >70+ MHz and then slow that down.

Destin, I beleive that the crackeling sound of the original audio at 1/10th of the speed comes down to the limitation of the sample rate. I don't know what you guys use for audio recording, but a standard A/D converter will sample at 44,1 kHz or maybe 88,2 kHz. Which are only 4k or 8k samples at a playback speed of 1/10th. Which is way to low for a D/A converter to produce any coherent soundwave.

There are gadgets out there that can record at higher rates, which gives you more data, which gives you a higher range to sensibly slow down the audio.

Even so, I think at the rates you are slowing down the video (1/1000), the audio will be "nonsense" anyways.

And I'm pretty sure the sound will not be as "engaging" and fitting as the one created by Gordon!!!

I just think the problem of low sample rates could be a great topic for a SmarterEveryDay video!

if you want to slow a video down to 100x slower, and then play it at 30. You have to record at 3000 fps. If you want to record the sound you have to also record "more" audio. Audio usually plays at 48 kHz, or 48000 Hertz, which means you have to multiply 48 kHz by 100 to match the audio with the video. Which is 4800000 Hertz, or 4800 kHz.

However, if you play this back at only 48 kHz, you will have a very long waveform which is way below the minimum of 20 Hertz a human can possibly hear. That means you cannot hear the sound..

(There is no way of recording at 4800 kHz yet so it won't work anyway... In theory it should work tho.)

Loved the video, couldn't help but to laugh. You're right, that guy is hilarious! I have to agree with some of these comments, though. While I think foley art is fascinating in its own right, and earns a tip of the hat for having fooled me thus far, I think it would be worth the effort to extract and accurately represent the actual audio data to use with the video. Sure, it sounds a lot like a Saturn V taking off, but that's the beauty of it!
Since the first time a giant monster destroyed a city on the silver screen, it has been obvious that slowing things down makes them seem bigger. The same is true for sound. I remember recording a coin falling on my desk, slowing down the audio, and being amazed how much it sounded like a manhole cover falling in the street.
The comments are full of ideas for recording a high enough sample rate to use; like optically, with suspended gold leaf and an exposure point on the high speed video. Some people say that expensive equipment already exists that would work. I though maybe you could use an array of microphones, recording at the same bit rate, but out of phase with each other. Either way, I feel like the community would be interested in a more comprehensive look into the idea, rather than the off-hand "that just sounds like a rocket"(paraphrased) dismissal it received.
Again, I fully enjoyed the video, and I thank you for helping to make me smarter every day!

I actually kind of wondered how it was done. I know that the Slowmo Guys said that high speed cameras don't record sound, and that they used to record the sound from a different source. I think they mentioned that they had to actually have sound made for the slow motion footage once they started getting to such high frame rates that the sound from a normal camera wouldn't work anymore. So, of course, now I've become smarter.

Now to pay it back. I'm sure you, Destin, know what the art is called in the film industry, but this will be for those who don't know. The technique is called Foley, and it is the art of adding sounds to footage that has no sound to it. And as shown in the previous video on adding sounds, Foley artists will use a wide range of objects, tools, and all sorts of strange and unusual techniques to make sounds to be added into footage. The current form of the technique has been around since the creation of "talkies," also known as the first movies to have sound and voice in addition to music. Though the technique has existed for far longer in a different form in theater. And I have to say, the way they accomplish that is some serious "magic" that was eventually applied to the film industry, and the art of Foley will continue to grow and improve with new technology, and those who are dedicated to preserving the techniques that make it what it is.

I know you can't record audio at 44.1 KHz and slow that down, but what if you were to record the audio at a much higher sample rate? The next issue would be that the playback would be in the infasonic range, so couldn't you then artificially increase the pitch of that audio so that the majority of the frequencies are within the 20 to 20,000 Hz range of human hearing?

There are techniques for slowing down audio without affecting pitch (granular and fft based methods come readily to mind), so the most honest reason for why foley audio is typically used for slow motion video is because it is used as an artistic effect to add drama; none of this nonsense that something derived from the live sound couldn't be used. It's just the same reason music is used in movies.

If I were going to try to slow down the live sound to get something interesting and fairly accurate, I'd record the audio at a typical sample rate and use one of the methods of extreme audio stretch that doesn't affect pitch. Along with that, I'd also record as high a sample rate as I could, slow that down with a simple change of sample rate, then process that recording into just transient impulses, and side chain it into various convolution processors that could be tweaked for artistic refinement and finer detail. The impulse responses for those convolution processors could even be separately recorded from the actual objects used in the footage.

This approach would use raw slowed down live audio but also allow some amount of artistic/dramatic tweaking that still uses live audio for at least a temporal basis. It probably wouldn't sound as "good (entertainment-wise)" as just doing foley, but it would be more actual data that could lead to insights that could be missed with only the visual data being used.

It sounds like a rocket because when you slow the waveform down by simply stretching the samples (i.e. "nearest neighbor" interpolation), you end up with sharp transitions where it jumps from one sample, repeated over several frames, to the next. This creates a high frequency component and makes that signature crackling sound. If you used bicubic interpolation to smooth out those samples, you would stay in the inaudible subsonic range.
My guess would be that pitch shifting sound is exactly like the Doppler effect; higher frequencies gets stretched which happens when a rocket is moving away from you.

The sound as we all know is made up out of waves. These waves are alternating. What we here when we slow it down very much is the individual ups and downs that start to be heard as seperate sounds, instead of the original "Sound" it was made up of. This is similar to the rocket launch because there we are hearing the wooshing sound of the oscilating waves underneath the rocket etc.

Many people seem to think that this is because of the microphone not being "fast" enough, but this is not really the problem. The issue is the sound itself - the way we experience sound as a wave (ie, a series of low and high pulses/transitions) means that the sound itself has a limited speed. If we record 10 frames per "wavefront" we can't slow it down because there is nothing to slow down! Think of it like there was a flashing light next to the banana. If it is flashing very, very fast (say 1000 times per second), it just seems like a dimmer version of it's non-flashing brother. But if we now slow down the footage, we can see that it is flashing on and off. We go from this continuous perception of brightness to a pulsing on-off light. There is no way to "slow down the light" because there is nothing to slow down.

I hope this makes any sense. Perhaps a simple animation or such could help here?
Adam Neely on youtube here did a video about this in a way, regarding music. The concept there was that if we have rythmic pulses going extremely fast, they would start sounding like low frequency tones. This is essentially the reverse: the tone is made out of low-frequency tones and waves, and if we slow down we start to hear the individual pulses and it sounds nothing like what we expect.

When I watched the first part of this and I heard that the sound in your slow motion videos was all Foley, my immediate feeling was one of betrayal. I had watched your previous slow motion videos highly impressed at your ability to capture the nuance of the sounds at such a high rates and I felt like I was actually hearing things that were beyond normal perception.
That being said, I am glad that you are being completely transparent about it, and have shown the process in detail so we can clearly understand what is going on.

I do, however, think it is a waste to completely disregard the actual audio. The segment shown in this video where you explained why you wouldn't use the actual sound revealed a fascinating parallel to the sounds of a rocket engine, and I'm certain there is very often value in slow motion sounds, even if pitched up to be audible or understandable (like the songs of a cricket that sound like bird songs when slowed down but pitched up). I do understand the entertainment value of using Foley, but I ask that you don't immediately disregard data that could be potentially valuable. Even the sounds of dominoes of different materials striking each other or sliding on different surfaces might be of actual interest.
